dt: {bc}the action or sport of fishing with hook and line

shortdef: the action of one who angles; especially : the action or sport of fishing with hook and line

dt: {bc}to turn, move, or direct at an angle

dt.t: slipped the key in and {it}angled{/it} it to one side

dt: {bc}to present (something, such as a news story) from a particular or prejudiced point of view {bc}{sx|slant||}

dt.t: {it}angled{/it} stories toward the newspaper's political preferences

et: Middle English {it}anglen{/it} "to meet at an angle," derivative of {it}angle{/it} {et_link|angle:1|angle:1}
shortdef: to turn or proceed at an angle
to turn, move, or direct at an angle
to present (something, such as a news story) from a particular or prejudiced point of view : slant

dt: {bc}to use artful means to attain an objective

et: Middle English {it}anglen,{/it} derivative of {it}angel{/it} "fishhook," going back to Old English {it}angel, ongel,{/it} going back to Germanic {it}*angula-{/it} "hook, barb" (whence also Old Saxon {it}angul{/it} "fishhook," Old High German, "hook, barb," Old Norse {it}ǫngull{/it} "fishhook"), going back to Indo-European {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}enk-ul-ó-,{/it} derivative, perhaps diminutive, of a base {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}enk-{/it} seen also in the n-stem noun {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}enk-ón-{/it} (whence Old English {it}anga{/it} "prick, goad," Old High German {it}ango{/it} "sting, barb, door hinge," Greek {it}ankṓn{/it} "bend, elbow"), suffixed in Greek {it}ankýlos{/it} "bent, crooked, curved," and as an o-grade derivative in Greek {it}ónkos{/it} "barb of an arrow," Latin {it}uncus{/it} "curved at the extremities, hooked, a hook," and probably Sanskrit {it}aṅkáḥ{/it} "curve, hook"; {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}enk-{/it} perhaps attested as a primary verb in Sanskrit {it}áñcati, ácati{/it} "(it) bends, curves"
Indo-European {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}enk-{/it} appears to be synonymous with the base {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eng-{/it} —see {et_link|angle:1|angle:1}, {et_link|ankle|ankle}.
shortdef: to use artful means to attain an objective
